report_title: Industry at a Glance: Martial Arts Studios
executive_summary: Martial arts studios have seen a fluctuating yet positive trajectory in recent years, buoyed by a steady climb in consumer spending. A renewed enthusiasm for martial arts contributed to climbing revenue as consumers increasingly recognized the multi-faceted benefits of sport, from physical wellness to mental discipline. Attendance levels are robust despite limited free time, supporting martial arts studios. Revenue has been climbing at a CAGR of 4.6% over the past five years to $19.4 billion in 2024, when revenue will expand by 1.7%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Martial arts instruction is a discretionary expense
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Martial arts instruction is a discretionary expense, leading consumers to cut it from their budgets when the economy wanes or disposable income diminishes. Despite this, consumer spending has been climbing, boosting studios' financial health.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Enthusiasm for martial arts grew steadily through 2024
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Although studio attendance dipped in 2020, enthusiasm for martial arts grew steadily through 2024. Sustained interest in the sport encouraged more individuals to invest in training and studio memberships, solidifying performance post-pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Martial arts' popularity as a healthy pastime promoted attendance
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Though free time for hobbies and sports has been limited, martial arts' popularity as a healthy pastime promoted continued attendance. The sport's multi-faceted benefits help maintain a steady stream of participants.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Growth Slows as External Competition Persists
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The growing presence of online fitness classes and alternative workouts will limit large-scale revenue growth for martial arts studios. Online platforms make accessing various fitness programs easier without visiting a physical studio.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Martial Arts Studios Will Lower Prices to Stay Competitive
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Price-based competition will drag down profit as martial arts studios will be forced to lower prices to compete. Numerous internal and external substitutes limit the ability to pass on rising operating costs to consumers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Franchising Model Will Bring Success to New Studios
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Establishing a solid reputation can be difficult for new martial arts schools, but many can overcome this barrier by opening as franchisees under a larger nationwide company.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Martial Arts Studios Will Become More Specialized
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The continued popularity of full-contact martial arts will promote attendance at gyms focusing on combat sports. This will help elevate the sport in line with its major competitors.

industry_definition: Martial arts studios, many of which operate as nonemployers, offer instruction in martial arts. These classes include karate, kendo, judo, jiu-jitsu, krav maga, taekwondo, muay thai and mixed martial arts, among others. This industry doesn't include self-defense or boxing instruction.
key_trends: Martial arts studios face strong price competition because of numerous internal and external alternatives. Ensuring affordable fees for potential students is essential for attracting and retaining clients.

Studios try to leverage their reputation. Training gyms that have well-renowned instructors can justify higher membership prices and martial arts schools compete with each other to hire and retain the best of the best.

MMA is seeing a surge in popularity, driven by interest in physical fitness. With its mix of disciplines like Brazilian jiu-jitsu and boxing, MMA offers a comprehensive training regimen that keeps people hooked.

Lowering prices means lower profit for studios. Martial arts studios are cutting prices to stay competitive, but it's hurting their bottom line. Rising operational costs and wages are piling on the pressure.

The industry is highly fragmented, so there aren't any major companies. Some large schools offer franchising opportunities, but the low barriers to entry allow new martial arts studios to pop up and serve local markets.

Demand is varied, so no company can capture significant market share. Consumers as a whole are interested in a wide range of martial disciplines, making it difficult for any company to gain a solid reputation across the industry's service offerings.
Regulation is light and varies by state. Rules aimed at protecting children involved in martial arts instruction are standard, and schools must abide by contract law when giving out memberships.

Most disciplines have private oversight organizations. Associations like the International Judo Federation help create a standard for competition and promote the practice of a given martial art. These organizations also offer accreditation services to elevate an instructor's credibility.
Martial arts studios' profits are under pressure because of economic strain. Rising costs and tighter consumer budgets mean folks are finding it harder to pay for classes.

Martial arts studios align with population trends. The Southeast, home to over a quarter of the US population, leads the nation in the number of martial arts facilities. Cities have more martial arts enthusiasts. Urban areas in California and the Mid-Atlantic see greater demand from potential students. This growth reflects a broader trend toward fitness and self-defense.
MMA is becoming more popular. Mixed martial arts (MMA) studios and Brazilian jiu-jitsu (BJJ) gyms are finding success amid the popularity of UFC.

Children are the primary market for martial arts studios. Parents enroll their kids in karate or taekwondo to promote physical, mental and social development. Attendance declines as children grow older and switch to football or weightlifting.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Despite making up less than 15.0% of the US population, children younger than 11 years old attend martial arts schools more than any other age group. Parents often put their young ones in martial arts training programs to promote physical and mental development. Notably, mixed martial arts (MMA) training is nearly nonexistent in this segment. Parents much prefer watching their young ones learn less-violent disciplines with little to no contact, like Karate or Judo.

Because their attention becomes divided between martial arts, social events and other extracurriculars like band or football, teenagers are a smaller market for martial arts studios. This segment remains the second-most-critical market for martial arts studios. Most students in this age range started at a younger age and have continued to practice as they've gotten older. Contact martial arts start to emerge in popularity in this age range.

This segment significantly drops off as a share of revenue as consumers graduate high school and become busy with college or enter the workforce. Still, these students often enjoy training in martial arts. Most students in this segment are training for fitness, but many compete in some capacity. While martial arts aren't NCAA sports, many organizations provide scholarships to students in this age range to continue training at an advanced level.

The third-largest market for martial arts studios is consumers between 25 and 34, as they have higher per capita disposable income and often choose to train in martial arts for recreational or fitness purposes. The majority of Olympic martial artists are also included in this segment, as the range is a sweet spot between experience and youth.

While many older adults still attend martial arts schools, the intense hands-on nature of most of the industry's disciplines make it a difficult task for aging consumers. Despite making up over half the nation's population, consumers over 35 account for less than a quarter of industry revenue.

While many older adults still attend martial arts schools, the intense hands-on nature of most of the industry's disciplines make it a difficult task for aging consumers. Despite making up over half the nation's population, consumers over 35 account for less than a quarter of industry revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) has historically been criticized for being dangerous, but regulations and evolving rules have made the sport safer for practitioners. MMA is full-contact and incorporates various striking and grappling techniques from many disciplines, so many students enjoy the wide range of skills MMA studios offer training in.

Karate originated in Okinawa, Japan but has spread across the world. Karate has its own system of strikes, blows, and open-hand techniques, which allow for careful scoring. This makes it a very popular competition sport. Created in Japan in the 19th century, judo directly translates to "gentle way." Because judo emphasizes grappling and takedowns over strikes, it's often considered less violent than other full-contact self-defense forms. This makes it more attractive to many consumers.

Brazilian jiu-jitsu (BJJ) emphasizes ground fighting and involves grappling, legwork, mounting, and submissions. The popularity of the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) has brought heightened visibility to BJJ, leading this segment to become the most popular discipline. Despite its overwhelming popularity, BJJ gyms are typically smaller with lower rates, as group sessions with students partnering up are much more common than one-on-one sessions. This leads to a lower overall profit for BJJ instructors.

Taekwondo combines self-defense techniques and combat moves with exercise and sport. Developed by combining various disciplines, including ancient Korean combat techniques, and has found success with consumers by being a solid mix of traditional practice and striking. Taekwondo became an Olympic sport in 2000 and is the single most popular option for martial arts enthusiasts.

There are about 180 different martial art forms worldwide, though none are as popular as the five listed above. Other disciplines include muay thai, capoeira, aikido, kung fu, kendo and many others. Krav Maga, a form of Israeli street fighting, has become increasingly popular with consumers primarily concerned with self-defense and was the most-viewed Wikipedia page from 2016 to 2020.

tier_1_suppliers: Sporting Goods Stores in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Sporting Goods Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Growth in consumer spending directly impacts martial arts studios. When consumer spending increases, individuals are more likely to allocate funds toward discretionary activities like martial arts instruction. This positive correlation suggests that growth in consumer spending leads to growth in revenue and represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: Martial arts schools in the US are closely aligned with population distribution, finding more presence in the Southeast, where the population is densest. This region has the highest number of martial arts schools, reflecting its large population and numerous local markets. The Southeast also includes more states than any other US region, offering plenty of local markets for small studios. This widespread market availability ensures martial arts studios can find a customer base and thrive. The Southeast's higher average age affects its share of revenue. Martial arts training primarily targets young children and teenagers, making regions with younger demographics potentially more lucrative.
California, the most populous state, naturally hosts the most martial arts studios. Dense metropolitan areas and higher disposable incomes contribute to the proliferation of studios in the region.

The Mid-Atlantic region has the third-highest number of martial arts schools in the United States. This is largely because of its dense metropolitan areas and large population. Urban settings make it easier for studios to attract students, thanks to high population density and a general interest in martial arts. The availability of transportation supports the concentration of training facilities in these areas. Major cities, including New York City, Philadelphia and Baltimore, are key hubs for martial arts training in the Mid-Atlantic.

regulations_points.regulation_description: State-level regulations primarily govern martial arts studios, especially regarding membership contracts. These laws often give members a few business days to cancel a contract after signing. Studios must meet standards related to their facilities and operational practices, such as insurance requirements. Failure to comply can result in legal penalties. In California, the Health Studio Services Act mandates a five-day cancellation window to protect consumers.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Accreditation is Helpful but Not Required
regulations_points.regulation_description: Martial arts schools aren't legally required to be accredited. Still, many seek accreditation to enhance their reputation and credibility. The World Karate Federation, offers accreditation for instructors who demonstrate a strong understanding of karate's rules. This certification ensures instructors can effectively teach the skills needed for competition and practice in the approved sport version. Accredited schools often attract more students and can command higher fees.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The NCYS Aims to Protect Children
regulations_points.regulation_description: The National Council of Youth Sports (NCYS) has set guidelines to prevent criminal behavior in youth sporting programs, including martial arts studios. These guidelines mandate comprehensive background checks on new hires, overseen by the National Center for Safety Initiatives (NCSI). Complying with these regulations helps martial arts schools enhance safety and credibility, crucial factors for attracting and retaining young students and their parents.

basis_points.basis_description: Martial arts studios face strong price competition because of numerous internal and external alternatives. Ensuring affordable fees for potential students is essential for attracting and retaining clients.

Studios try to leverage their reputation. Training gyms that have well-renowned instructors can justify higher membership prices and martial arts schools compete with each other to hire and retain the best of the best.

concentration_points.concentration_description: It's relatively cheap to open a new martial arts studio, so new entrants are regularly joining the industry and competing for local demand.

This has led the industry to be dominated by owner-operator martial arts studios that rarely engage in consolidation. Martial arts studios employ very few workers on average, leaving the industry heavily fragmented.

There are about 180 martial arts disciplines consumers may wish to learn, but studios tend to focus on only one or two styles. This means demand is varied and studios can typically find their own niche.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages are the Largest Single Expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest single expense for martial arts studios is employee pay, since capable instructors are needed to train students. Martial arts training is extremely labor-intensive.
One-on-one training can give a competitive edge to some studios, those this offer comes with heightened wage expenses.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Costs Help Run the Business
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Insurance minimums are essential in this industry, as injuries are somewhat commonplace given the physical combat involved in most instruction. Expenses associated with running a business in any industry, like administrative costs and accountant fees, are also included in this segment.

Martial arts studios need to buy equipment to properly conduct training, though this varies by which discipline a studio is focused on. Fencing studios will need epees and protective uniforms, while aikido dojos will need bokkens and jos.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Martial arts instruction demands skilled and trained instructors. New studios often find it challenging to manage labor costs while maintaining a low instructor-to-student ratio, which is crucial for student success.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic Downturns Severely Impact Martial Arts Studios
volatility_points.volatility_description: Martial arts training is a discretionary expense. Economic fluctuations significantly impact participation rates, with changes in per capita disposable income, consumer confidence and national unemployment rates being crucial factors.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumer Preference Can Elevate Volatility for Each School
volatility_points.volatility_description: The surge in Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) popularity has redirected consumer interest from traditional martial arts studios, such as karate gyms, to mixed martial arts (MMA) schools, which has affected the stability of traditional studios.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Virtual and Hybrid Classes Provide Flexibility
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Martial arts studios now offer virtual classes, enabling students to train from home. Hybrid classes allow participation either in-person or remotely, providing more options.

Studios invest in high-quality cameras and microphones to ensure effective and engaging virtual classes. This technological infrastructure aims to create a seamless training experience for remote students.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Personalized Training Programs Cater to Specific Needs
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Martial arts studios are introducing personalized training programs tailored to individual goals, fitness levels and needs. These programs often include one-on-one sessions, personalized nutrition plans and strength and conditioning workouts.

FAQs.question: Has the demographic breakdown of your client base changed in recent years?
FAQs.answer: As martial arts have become more popular, younger students have been attracted to the sport. The number of students under the age of 17 now makes up nearly half of all clients at martial arts studios.

FAQs.question: Have you changed your educational offerings to adapt to changing student interests?
FAQs.answer: Mixed martial arts have exploded in popularity during the past two decades, spurring a rise in studios that specialize in mixed martial arts.

FAQs.question: Has your company considered expanding operations to include more locations?
FAQs.answer: Because of the large number of small companies competing across local markets, franchising offers the competitive advantage of brand-name recognition.

FAQs.question: How has your company been affected by the economic dynamics in your area?
FAQs.answer: Demand for martial arts instruction is driven by the health of the economy. When unemployment declines and disposable income and consumer confidence rise, demand for martial arts instruction typically grows.

FAQs.question: What technologies have companies implemented during the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Martial arts studios have taken advantage of online and mobile technologies to streamline the registration, check-in and sign-up processes.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer online and telecommunication-based learning portals?
FAQs.answer: Some martial arts studios offer personalized online instruction to mimic in-person sessions.

FAQs.question: How does your studio ensure all health safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) offers free consultations to small business employers to identify potential hazards at work sites.

FAQs.question: Is your company subject to any franchising laws?
FAQs.answer: There are specific laws pertinent to franchise-run companies.
